review.title: A Formal Methods Approach to Pattern Synthesis in Reaction Diffusion Systems
review.abstract: We propose a technique to detect and generate patterns in a network of locally interacting dynamical systems. Central to our approach is a novel spatial superposition logic, whose semantics is defined over the quad-tree of a partitioned image. We show that formulas in this logic can be efficiently learned from positive and negative examples of several types of patterns. We also demonstrate that pattern detection, which is implemented as a model checking algorithm, performs very well for test data sets different from the learning sets. We define a quantitative semantics for the logic and integrate the model checking algorithm with particle swarm optimization in a computational framework for synthesis of parameters leading to desired patterns in reaction-diffusion systems.

sections.heading: V. TSSL PATTERN CLASSIFIERS
sections.text: However, it is difficult to write a formula that describes a desired property, such as a pattern. Here, we suggest using machine learning techniques to find such a formula of predefined sets of positive (Y +) and negative (Y −) values. We first define a labeled data collection from the given data sets Y + and Y − asL = {(Qy, +) | y label Y +} {(Qy, −) | y label Y −} in which QTS is generated from y. Then we separate the data set L into disjoint training and testing sets LL, LT. In machine learning, the training set is used to learn a classification for a target class, such as +, and the test set is used to measure the accuracy of the classification.

sections.heading: VI. PARAMETER SYNTHESIS FOR PATTERN GENERATION
sections.text: In this section we present the solution to problem 3.1, i.e. a framework for synthesizing parameters p-P of a reaction diffusion system S (III.1) in such a way that the observations of the system S (p) fulfill a given TSSL formula Φ. First, we show that the parameters of a reaction diffusion system satisfying the TSSL formula can be found by optimizing quantitative model verification results. Second, we conclude the optimization in a supervised iterative procedure for parameter synthesis. We easily abuse the terminology and say that an orbit x (t), t-0 of the system S (p) is satisfactory if the QTS Q = (S, s), the L) of the corresponding observation, H (t), is satisfactory.

sections.heading: VII. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: We have shown that formulas in this logic can be efficiently learned from positive and negative examples. We have defined a quantitative semantics for TSSL and combined it with an optimization algorithm to develop a supervised, iterative method for synthesizing pattern production parameters. While the experiments show that the current version of logic works quite well and can accommodate translation and rotation symmetries that are common in biological patterns, there are several directions of future work. First, we expect that even better results could be obtained if more statistical moments were used, and not just the mean as in the current version of this work. Second, we do not use the full semantics of logic in this essay. In future work, we plan to study the argument across several branches and apply the operator "to." Third, we plan to apply this method to more realistic methods that can be used in synthetic networks to generate synthetic patterns that we expect from existing cells.

referenceMentions.context: From the stripes of a zebra and the spots on a leopard to the filaments (Anabaena) [1], spirals, squares (Thiopedia rosea), and vortex (Paenibacillus) [2] formed by singlecell organisms, patterns can be found everywhere in nature.

From the stripes of a zebra and the spots on a leopard to the filaments (Anabaena) [1], spirals, squares (Thiopedia rosea), and vortex (Paenibacillus) [2] formed by singlecell organisms, patterns can be found everywhere in nature.

Pattern recognition is usually formulated as a machine learning problem [3], in which patterns are characterized either statistically [4] or through a structural relationship among their features [5].
Despite its success in several application areas [6], pattern recognition still lacks a formal foundation.
model checking [7], [8], we provide partial answers to these questions.

While the overall algorithm can, in principle, be applied to any network of locally interacting systems, in this paper we focus on the Turing reaction-diffusion system [9], and show that patternproducing parameters can be automatically generated with our method.

As opposed to [20], we also define a quantitative semantics for the logic, and use the distance to satisfaction as a fitness function while searching for pattern-producing parameters.

This quantitative semantics and the discounted model checking on a computational tree are inspired from [21], with the notable difference that we do not need a metric distance, but rather a measure of satisfiability.

The TSSL logic resembles the classic CTL logic [25], with the main difference that the next and until are not temporal, but spatial operators meaning a change of resolution (or zoom in).
For this reason we equip our logic also with a quantitative valuation that provides a measure of satisfiability in the same spirit of [17].

metadata.abstractText: We propose a technique to detect and generate patterns in a network of locally interacting dynamical systems. Central to our approach is a novel spatial superposition logic, whose semantics is defined over the quad-tree of a partitioned image. We show that formulas in this logic can be efficiently learned from positive and negative examples of several types of patterns. We also demonstrate that pattern detection, which is implemented as a model checking algorithm, performs very well for test data sets different from the learning sets. We define a quantitative semantics for the logic and integrate the model checking algorithm with particle swarm optimization in a computational framework for synthesis of parameters leading to desired patterns in reaction-diffusion systems.
